title: (wip) PDK Templating v2.0
last_comment:
I am a bit against reworking the template system. Not because I think it doesn't require rework, but currently when I tell my clients about pdk-templates I just say it works like modulesync. Which is well documented and used by many.  

While, the current implementation isn't perfect, making the user switch to another system is going to piss them off.   Many users coming from the modulesync workflow will start using pdksync with PDK.  So for a large corporation to convert to PDK and forgetting everything about how modulesync is a hard pill to swallow.

Regarding the opt-in strategy.  This seems ideal.  I like it.  

The way I use pdk-templates is always the same:
1. Mirror official external templates into internal git repository
2. Fork the internal mirror into a namespace that is intended for heavy internal usage
3. Make changes that are reflective to my environment
4. Remove all calls to the internet (rubygems.org, puppet.com, github.com)
5. Add all my exclusions to the template_configs
6. Create branches for each tag of the upstream templates

With this in mind there should be an air-gaped setting too.  Provide a way to fill in special environment variables in the templates.yml that are then used in the template rendering.

```yaml

pdk_templates:
  config: 
    air_gaped: true
    GEM_SOURCE: "ENV['GEM_SOURCE']"
    ci_system:
      - travis
      - appveyor
    scm_system: github_enterprise
    upstream_template_repo: github.com/puppetlabs/pdk-templates
    internal_template_repo: github.com/nwops/pdk-templates  
```

On a side note.  What I would like to see is the templates.yml file become the configuration code for describing an environment.  Take the upstream pdk-templates from puppet and "merge" them with an internal (subset).  Whereby,  the internal subset files take precedence over the upstream version. This should be similar in behavior to `Hash.merge.`   What this might look like:

1. pdk new module --template_url=https://github.com/nwops/pdk-templates.git
2. pdk clones https://github.com/nwops/pdk-templates.git
3. pdk references the templates.yml file and finds the upstream_template_repo
4. pdk clones the upstream template repo
5. pdk starts to create new files and looks for template in internal_template_repo first and fails back to upstream templates for the requested template. 

This keeps the user from having to keep an extra fork of pdk-templates around and constantly maintain them with upstream changes.

title: Remove all sub-folders from source repository / folder
last_comment:
> This seems likely to be correct. Can you elaborate on the steps you took or the module/repo involved that generated the error?
It internal modules which has general structure:
```
module_name
├── lib
├── manifests
└── templates
```
this module is part of Puppet code base so it lives in *site* directory:
```
puppet (root of code base)
 ├── site
   ├── module_name
     ├── lib
     ├── manifests
     └── templates
```
As you can see module can contain manifests folder so it is in conflict with manifests folder in root path of code base.

title: (PDK-1047) Add rake task to inspect module for class & defined type definitions
last_comment:
> What I was saying is that retrospec already does the thing being built here.

The goal of PDK-1047 is not to implement retrospec style functionality. We do not want to inspect the contents of the class or defined types to generate extensive tests for all the contained resources.

> Test generators suffer from the problem that most people using them have no clue how to write or maintain the tests it creates. Test Education is more important IMHO.

The scope of this is simply to be able to examine a module during `pdk convert` and feed this information into the existing PDK object generators so that the *very minimal* template specs are generated, the same specs that are generated by running `pdk new class` or `pdk new defined_type`.

These generated tests are little more than `it { is_expected.to compile }`, which we've found is enough for most users.

title: [RFC] New syntax
last_comment:
How would this deal with resources within a module? given the current double underscore I'd expect `describe concat__fragment('x') do ... end`

Another thing I'd like to see is easy verification of the full content. Currently we have helper functions:
```
def verify_concat_fragment_contents(subject, title, expected_lines)
  is_expected.to contain_concat__fragment(title)
  content = subject.resource('concat::fragment', title).send(:parameters)[:content]
  expect(content.split("\n") & expected_lines).to match_array(expected_lines)
end

def verify_concat_fragment_exact_contents(subject, title, expected_lines)
  is_expected.to contain_concat__fragment(title)
  content = subject.resource('concat::fragment', title).send(:parameters)[:content]
  expect(content.split(/\n/).reject { |line| line =~ /(^#|^$|^\s+#)/ }).to match_array(expected_lines)
end
```

title: Adds the ability to spec test an arbitrary string
last_comment:
Hmm. I'm not opposed to that idea, but how would we be able to invoke a spec programmatically then? We're using this now like so:

``` ruby
  def run_rspec(spec_path, str)
    require 'rspec/core'

    # rspec needs an IO object to write to. We just want it as a string...
    data = StringIO.new
    RSpec::configure do |c|
        c.output_stream = data
        c.formatter     = 'json'
    end

    # require *after* setting the output stream or it screams at us
    # String input depends on https://github.com/rodjek/rspec-puppet/pull/619
    require 'rspec-puppet'
    RSpec::configure do |c|
        c.string        = str
    end

    begin
        RSpec::Core::Runner.run([spec_path])
        return data.string
    rescue StandardError, LoadError => e
        return "Error running spec test: #{e.message}",
end
```
